posts.title: Welcome
posts.markdown: Hi guys! Welcome to my blog. I'm currently a Monash student studying Computer Science, and am just about to finish a placement at Australia Post which I've been on for the last 5 months. I've been learning lots there so I plan to start off my blog by talking about that a little bit. Stay tuned!
posts.html: Hi guys! Welcome to my blog. I'm currently a Monash student studying Computer Science, and am just about to finish a placement at Australia Post which I've been on for the last 5 months. I've been learning lots there so I plan to start off my blog by talking about that a little bit. Stay tuned!

posts.title: Make your own static blog using Ghost and Buster
posts.markdown:
You can easily make your own blog for free by using [Ghost](https://ghost.org/) with [Buster](https://github.com/axitkhurana/buster/) and deploying it to your own [Github Page](https://pages.github.com/). Ghost is an opensource blogging platform which is [highly configurable with themes](http://marketplace.ghost.org/). You can download and run it yourself, or alternatively use their own hosting service which requires payment after the free trial period. You can use Buster to turn your blog into a static site, and deploy it directly to your GitHub Page.

#### Setup
1. Make your own GitHub Pages repo as described [here](https://pages.github.com/), although you'll need to leave it empty for Buster to work.
2. Make sure you have [NodeJS and NPM installed](http://nodejs.org/download/).
3. Download and unzip Ghost [here](https://ghost.org/download/). In this directory, run:
 
	    npm install --production
        npm start

	 Ghost should start up on http://localhost:2368.
4. Go to http://localhost:2368/ghost/ and enter you information into the forms to get to the admin panel. From here you can publish blog posts, edit your blog information, select different themes, and edit your user profile.
5. Install PIP [here](https://pip.pypa.io/en/latest/installing.html) and follow the directions. 
6. Run: 
 
        buster setup --gh-repo='your GitHub Pages repo URL'
        buster generate --domain=localhost:2368
        buster deploy

Well done! Your blog should now be pushed to your GitHub Pages repo, and will be live at http://username.github.io shortly. Be patient. The first deployment always takes the longest, and could take up to 40 minutes. I've also had other updates take over 10 minutes to be reflected in production.
New themes must go into ````Ghost-root/content/themes/````, and if you'd like to like to play around with making your own theme or edit an existing theme from the marketplace, Ghost have a [very good guide](http://themes.ghost.org/). The theme used for this blog can be found [here](https://github.com/cwhitey/crisp-ghost-theme).

#### Issues
I keep my entire ghost source in a separate GitHub repo so I can make blog changes from any machine configured with nodejs and Buster. However, when doing a ````buster deploy```` from a different machine, I often get the following error:


```bash
...
error: failed to push some refs to 'https://github.com/cwhitey/cwhitey.github.io.git'
hint: Updates were rejected because the remote contains work that you do
hint: not have locally. This is usually caused by another repository pushing
hint: to the same ref. You may want to first integrate the remote changes
hint: (e.g., 'git pull ...') before pushing again.
hint: See the 'Note about fast-forwards' in 'git push --help' for details.
```

To get it deployed I've had to copy the contents of the ````static/```` directory populated by the ````buster generate```` into my GitHub Pages repo, then push it manually:
    
```bash    
git add --all
git commit -m "your message"
git push -f
```

As you will be doing this entire process regularly, you may decide to just write a single script to do it for you. I wrote the following for this purpose:

<script src="https://gist.github.com/cwhitey/205aed89c0cb75553d07.js"></script>
posts.html:
You can easily make your own blog for free by using Ghost with Buster and deploying it to your own Github Page. Ghost is an opensource blogging platform which is highly configurable with themes. You can download and run it yourself, or alternatively use their own hosting service which requires payment after the free trial period. You can use Buster to turn your blog into a static site, and deploy it directly to your GitHub Page.

Setup

  1. Make your own GitHub Pages repo as described here, although you'll need to leave it empty for Buster to work.
  2. Make sure you have NodeJS and NPM installed.

  3. Download and unzip Ghost here. In this directory, run:

    npm install --production
npm start

    Ghost should start up on http://localhost:2368.

  4. Go to http://localhost:2368/ghost/ and enter you information into the forms to get to the admin panel. From here you can publish blog posts, edit your blog information, select different themes, and edit your user profile.
  5. Install PIP here and follow the directions.

  6. Run: 

    buster setup --gh-repo='your GitHub Pages repo URL'
buster generate --domain=localhost:2368
buster deploy

Well done! Your blog should now be pushed to your GitHub Pages repo, and will be live at http://username.github.io shortly. Be patient. The first deployment always takes the longest, and could take up to 40 minutes. I've also had other updates take over 10 minutes to be reflected in production.
New themes must go into Ghost-root/content/themes/, and if you'd like to like to play around with making your own theme or edit an existing theme from the marketplace, Ghost have a very good guide. The theme used for this blog can be found here.

Issues

I keep my entire ghost source in a separate GitHub repo so I can make blog changes from any machine configured with nodejs and Buster. However, when doing a buster deploy from a different machine, I often get the following error:

...
error: failed to push some refs to 'https://github.com/cwhitey/cwhitey.github.io.git'  
hint: Updates were rejected because the remote contains work that you do  
hint: not have locally. This is usually caused by another repository pushing  
hint: to the same ref. You may want to first integrate the remote changes  
hint: (e.g., 'git pull ...') before pushing again.  
hint: See the 'Note about fast-forwards' in 'git push --help' for details.

To get it deployed I've had to copy the contents of the static/ directory populated by the buster generate into my GitHub Pages repo, then push it manually:

git add --all  
git commit -m "your message"  
git push -f

As you will be doing this entire process regularly, you may decide to just write a single script to do it for you. I wrote the following for this purpose:

posts.title: Helpful Clojure resources
posts.markdown:
During my placement at Australia Post I spent a lot of time using Clojure. Clojure is a functional language on the JVM with LISP-like syntax. I've really enjoyed learning and using Clojure and, although I'm still learning, I've used some resources along the way which I think are great for Clojure beginners.

### Setup
* [Light Table](http://www.lighttable.com/) - A good IDE for learning Clojure.
* [Emacs](http://www.braveclojure.com/basic-emacs/) - Alternatively, you can start off using Emacs. It has a higher learning curve but is highly configurable and works really well with Lisp-based languages.
* [Leiningen](http://leiningen.org/) - Tool for easy Clojure project and dependency management **(mandatory)**.

### Tutorials
* [Learn X in Y Minutes](http://learnxinyminutes.com/docs/clojure/) - Quickest way to get a brief understanding of Clojure syntax.
* [puredanger's Tutorial](http://tech.puredanger.com/2010/02/08/clojure-1-whats-up-doc/) - Written by an active Clojure contributer.
* [Brave Clojure](http://www.braveclojure.com/) - Very extensive but sometimes a little hard to follow.
* [Fast Track Clojure](http://fasttrackclojure.blogspot.com.au/2010/09/lesson-1-hello-clojure.html)
* [Destructuring Tutorial/Reference](https://gist.github.com/john2x/e1dca953548bfdfb9844)

### Challenges
* [4clojure](https://www.4clojure.com/)
* [Clojure Koans](http://clojurekoans.com/)
* [Exercism](http://exercism.io/) - Exercises for 19 different languages, including Clojure.
* [Project Euler](https://projecteuler.net/) - Language agnostic, but these challenges taught me a lot about how to solve algorithms in a functional way vs imperative.

### Books
* [Programming Clojure - Pragmatic Programmers](https://pragprog.com/book/shcloj2/programming-clojure)
* [Clojure Programming - O'Reilly](http://shop.oreilly.com/product/0636920013754.do)
* [Clojure Cookbook - O'Reilly](http://shop.oreilly.com/product/0636920029786.do)

### Web Development
* [Clojure Web Dev](http://clojurewebdev.com/) - A great introduction to web development in Clojure. Contains a very informative talk about building a backend supported web application, and includes code snippets and resources for further study.
* [What Web Framework Should I Use?](http://www.lispcast.com/what-web-framework-should-i-use)
* [Luminus](http://www.luminusweb.net/) - A great Leiningen template for setting up skeletons of Clojure webapps with various component configurations. It's accompanied by some very informative docs which make learning web development in Clojure much easier.

### Documentation & Tools
* [tryclj](http://tryclj.com/) - An online REPL.
* [grimoire](http://grimoire.arrdem.com/) - One of the best online references for Clojure documentation.
* [Clojure Toolbox](http://www.clojure-toolbox.com/) - An organised collection of useful libraries and tools for Clojure.
* [ClojureWerks](http://clojurewerkz.org/) - Another collection of quality Clojure libraries and their documentation.
* [Clojure Sphere](http://www.clojuresphere.com/) - A listing of statistics for components in the Clojure ecosystem.
* [Clojure Docs](https://clojuredocs.org/) - Community-powered clojure documentation.
* [lein-bikeshed](https://github.com/dakrone/lein-bikeshed) - A Leiningen plugin which scans your project for bad code.

I've really enjoyed learning and using Clojure and, although I'm still learning, I've used some resources along the way which I think are great for Clojure beginners.

  • What Web Framework Should I Use?
  • Luminus - A great Leiningen template for setting up skeletons of Clojure webapps with various component configurations. It's accompanied by some very informative docs which make learning web development in Clojure much easier.

posts.title: Helpful ClojureScript resources
posts.markdown:
### Tutorials
* [modern-cljs](https://github.com/magomimmo/modern-cljs)


### Books
* [ClojureScript: Up and Running - O'Reilly](http://shop.oreilly.com/product/0636920025139.do)


### Frameworks
* [Reagent][1] - Minimalistic interface to ReactJS. The [Reagent Cookbook][2] and the [Reagent Template][3] are available to help you learn Reagent and set up your Reagent projects.
* [Quiescent][4] - Another lightwith interface to ReactJS.
* [Om][5] - A much heavier interface to ReactJS than [Quiescent][4] and [Reagent][1], but provides many more features.
* [Gyr][6] - An interface to AngularJS. An example can be found [here][7].

[1]: https://github.com/reagent-project/reagent
[2]: https://github.com/reagent-project/reagent-cookbook
[3]: https://github.com/reagent-project/reagent-template
[4]: https://github.com/levand/quiescent
[5]: https://github.com/swannodette/om
[6]: http://purnam.github.io/gyr/
[7]: https://github.com/purnam/example.gyr


### Documentation & Tools
* [Austin REPL](https://github.com/cemerick/austin) - A ClojureScript REPL which is quick and easy to use and provides a bunch of useful utilities.
posts.html:
Tutorials

  • modern-cljs

Books

  • ClojureScript: Up and Running - O'Reilly

Frameworks

  • Reagent - Minimalistic interface to ReactJS. The Reagent Cookbook and the Reagent Template are available to help you learn Reagent and set up your Reagent projects.
  • Quiescent - Another lightwith interface to ReactJS.
  • Om - A much heavier interface to ReactJS than Quiescent and Reagent, but provides many more features.
  • Gyr - An interface to AngularJS. An example can be found here.

Documentation & Tools

  • Austin REPL - A ClojureScript REPL which is quick and easy to use and provides a bunch of useful utilities.

posts.title: My Emacs setup
posts.markdown:
I've been learning how to use Emacs for several months for Clojure development. I thought I would document my initial setup here and continue updating it as I find new packages and develop more useful/convenient keybindings. You can also find my up to date ````.emacs.d```` in my [dotfiles](https://github.com/cwhitey/dotfiles) GitHub repo.

I tried various starter kits such as [Prelude](https://github.com/bbatsov/prelude), [Emacs Starter Kit](https://github.com/technomancy/emacs-starter-kit) and [Emacs Live](https://github.com/overtone/emacs-live). I eventually settled with Emacs Live for a couple of months. After getting frustrated while trying to (unsuccessfully) modify the Emacs Live setup, I started looking for other options. I then stumbled on [oh-my-emacs](https://github.com/xiaohanyu/oh-my-emacs). Oh-my-emacs provides you with a completely documented starting setup which benefits both beginners and experts of Emacs. It's configuration is contained within ````.org```` files which contains Emacs Lisp code within ````#+BEGIN_SRC```` and ````#+END_SRC```` tags. The ````.org```` files get parsed into ````.el```` files during Emacs initialisation, and you can prevent snippets of Emacs Lisp code from being parsed by changing ````#+BEGIN_SRC emacs-lisp```` to ````#+BEGIN_SRC emacs-lisp :tangle no````.




##### Installation:
* Mac: [Emacs Mac port](https://github.com/railwaycat/emacs-mac-port)
* Linux: Your Linux distro's package manager will likely contain Emacs.

##### Setup:
Install oh-my-emacs by following these [Quick Start steps](https://github.com/xiaohanyu/oh-my-emacs#quick-start).

#### The following requires updates...
##### Configuration:
1. Add melpa archives

        (add-to-list 'package-archives
                     '("melpa" . "http://melpa.milkbox.net/packages/"))
                 
2. Mac user keys

        (global-set-key (kbd "M-c") 'copy-region-as-kill)
        (global-set-key (kbd "M-v") 'yank)
        (global-set-key (kbd "M-z") 'undo)
3. [NeoTree](http://www.emacswiki.org/emacs/NeoTree)

        (global-set-key [f8] 'neotree-toggle)
4. [WindMove](http://www.emacswiki.org/emacs/WindMove) 

        (when (fboundp 'windmove-default-keybindings)
              (windmove-default-keybindings 'alt))
5. Undo an undo

        (global-set-key (kbd "C-S-/") 'undo-tree-redo)
6. Fullscreen a frame

        (global-set-key (kbd "C-c m") 'toggle-frame-maximized)
posts.html:
I've been learning how to use Emacs for several months for Clojure development. I thought I would document my initial setup here and continue updating it as I find new packages and develop more useful/convenient keybindings. You can also find my up to date .emacs.d in my dotfiles GitHub repo.

I tried various starter kits such as Prelude, Emacs Starter Kit and Emacs Live. I eventually settled with Emacs Live for a couple of months. After getting frustrated while trying to (unsuccessfully) modify the Emacs Live setup, I started looking for other options. I then stumbled on oh-my-emacs. Oh-my-emacs provides you with a completely documented starting setup which benefits both beginners and experts of Emacs. It's configuration is contained within .org files which contains Emacs Lisp code within #+BEGIN_SRC and #+END_SRC tags. The .org files get parsed into .el files during Emacs initialisation, and you can prevent snippets of Emacs Lisp code from being parsed by changing #+BEGIN_SRC emacs-lisp to #+BEGIN_SRC emacs-lisp :tangle no.

Installation:
  • Mac: Emacs Mac port
  • Linux: Your Linux distro's package manager will likely contain Emacs.
Setup:

Install oh-my-emacs by following these Quick Start steps.

The following requires updates...

Configuration:

  1. Add melpa archives

    (add-to-list 'package-archives
             '("melpa" . "http://melpa.milkbox.net/packages/"))

  2. Mac user keys

    (global-set-key (kbd "M-c") 'copy-region-as-kill)
(global-set-key (kbd "M-v") 'yank)
(global-set-key (kbd "M-z") 'undo)

  3. NeoTree

    (global-set-key [f8] 'neotree-toggle)

  4. WindMove 

    (when (fboundp 'windmove-default-keybindings)
      (windmove-default-keybindings 'alt))

  5. Undo an undo

    (global-set-key (kbd "C-S-/") 'undo-tree-redo)

  6. Fullscreen a frame

    (global-set-key (kbd "C-c m") 'toggle-frame-maximized)

posts.title: Choosing a Clojure web template
posts.markdown: I recently started a small pet project which will run as a web application with backend support. I wanted to use Clojure and ClojureScript for it, but was starting out with a minimal amount of web development experience, and no experience with ClojureScript (or Javascript). For this reason I decided look into which Leiningen templates are available for creating webapps and choose the one that best suits my needs. I'm documenting what I learned about each template here on the chance it will benefit others, and so I can refer back to it later when starting other projects. To use a template: `lein new ` 1. [cljs-webapp](https://github.com/mihneadb/cljs-webapp) ([File structure](#cljs-webapp-files)) 2. [lein-webapp-template](https://github.com/eprunier/lein-webapp-template) ([File structure](#lein-webapp-template-files)) 3. [Compojure](https://github.com/weavejester/compojure) ([File structure](#compojure-files)) 4. [reagent-template](https://github.com/reagent-project/reagent-template) ([File structure](#reagent-template-files)) 5. [Hoplon](http://hoplon.io/#/getting-started/) ([File structure](#hoplon-files)) 6. [Luminus](http://www.luminusweb.net/) ([File structure](#luminus-files)) 7. [pedestal-service]() ([File structure](#pedestal-service-files)) There's also a [workshop](https://github.com/rkneufeld/pedestal-workshop) for Pedestal, and a template for creating microservices called [pedestal-micro](https://github.com/rkneufeld/pedestal-micro). ##### Web template file structures 1. [cljs-webapp](https://github.com/mihneadb/cljs-webapp) cljs-webapp-app ├── LICENSE ├── project.clj ├── resources │   └── public │   └── index.html └── src-cljs └── cljs_webapp_app └── core.cljs 2. [lein-webapp-template](https://github.com/eprunier/lein-webapp-template) lein-webapp-template-app ├── dev │   └── user.clj ├── project.clj ├── README.md ├── resources │   └── public │   ├── css │   │   └── ... │   ├── fonts │   │   └── ... │   └── js │   └── ... └── src ├── lein_webapp_template_app │   ├── app.clj │   ├── middleware │   │   ├── context.clj │   │   └── session.clj │   ├── server.clj │   ├── service │   │   └── db.clj │   ├── util │   │   ├── flash.clj │   │   └── session.clj │   └── view │   ├── about.clj │   └── ... └── lein_webapp_template_app.clj 3. [Compojure](https://github.com/weavejester/compojure) compojure-app ├── project.clj ├── README.md ├── resources │   └── public ├── src │   └── compojure_app │   └── core │   └── handler.clj └── test └── compojure_app └── core └── handler_test.clj 4. [reagent-template](https://github.com/reagent-project/reagent-template) reagent-app ├── env │   ├── dev │   │   └── cljs │   │   └── reagent │   │   └── dev.cljs │   └── prod │   └── cljs │   └── reagent │   └── prod.cljs ├── project.clj ├── README.md ├── resources │   ├── public │   │   └── css │   │   └── site.css │   └── templates │   └── index.html └── src    ├── clj    │   └── reagent    │   ├── dev.clj    │   └── handler.clj    └── cljs    └── reagent    └── core.cljs 5. [Hoplon](http://hoplon.io/#/getting-started/) 6. [Luminus](http://www.luminusweb.net/) 7. [pedestal-service]()
posts.html:
I recently started a small pet project which will run as a web application with backend support. I wanted to use Clojure and ClojureScript for it, but was starting out with a minimal amount of web development experience, and no experience with ClojureScript (or Javascript). For this reason I decided look into which Leiningen templates are available for creating webapps and choose the one that best suits my needs. I'm documenting what I learned about each template here on the chance it will benefit others, and so I can refer back to it later when starting other projects.

To use a template: lein new <template-name> <project-name>

  1. cljs-webapp (File structure)

  2. lein-webapp-template (File structure)

  3. Compojure (File structure)

  4. reagent-template (File structure)

  5. Hoplon (File structure)

  6. Luminus (File structure)

  7. pedestal-service (File structure)
    There's also a workshop for Pedestal, and a template for creating microservices called pedestal-micro.

Web template file structures

  1. cljs-webapp

    cljs-webapp-app
├── LICENSE
├── project.clj
├── resources
│   └── public
│       └── index.html
└── src-cljs
    └── cljs_webapp_app
        └── core.cljs

  2. lein-webapp-template

    lein-webapp-template-app
├── dev
│   └── user.clj
├── project.clj
├── README.md
├── resources
│   └── public
│       ├── css
│       │   └── ...
│       ├── fonts
│       │   └── ...
│       └── js
│           └── ...
└── src
    ├── lein_webapp_template_app
    │   ├── app.clj
    │   ├── middleware
    │   │   ├── context.clj
    │   │   └── session.clj
    │   ├── server.clj
    │   ├── service
    │   │   └── db.clj
    │   ├── util
    │   │   ├── flash.clj
    │   │   └── session.clj
    │   └── view
    │       ├── about.clj
    │       └── ...
    └── lein_webapp_template_app.clj

  3. Compojure

    compojure-app
├── project.clj
├── README.md
├── resources
│   └── public
├── src
│   └── compojure_app
│       └── core
│           └── handler.clj
└── test
    └── compojure_app
        └── core
            └── handler_test.clj

  4. reagent-template

    reagent-app
├── env
│   ├── dev
│   │   └── cljs
│   │       └── reagent
│   │           └── dev.cljs
│   └── prod
│       └── cljs
│           └── reagent
│               └── prod.cljs
├── project.clj
├── README.md
├── resources
│   ├── public
│   │   └── css
│   │       └── site.css
│   └── templates
│       └── index.html
└── src
    ├── clj
    │   └── reagent
    │       ├── dev.clj
    │       └── handler.clj
    └── cljs
        └── reagent
            └── core.cljs

  5. Hoplon

  6. Luminus

  7. pedestal-service

posts.title: About
posts.markdown: I am a Computer Science student and software developer living in Melbourne, Australia. I currently have a special interest in functional programming.
posts.html: I am a Computer Science student and software developer living in Melbourne, Australia. I currently have a special interest in functional programming.

posts.title: Disclaimer
posts.markdown:
This is my blog. This means that the opinions expressed on this site are my own and do not reflect the opinions of my employees, employers, associates, affiliates, friends, or family. 

Please keep in mind that all data and information provided on this site is for informational purposes only. I make no representations as to accuracy, completeness, currentness, suitability, or validity of any information on this site and will not be liable for any errors, omissions, or delays in this information or any losses, injuries, or damages arising from its display or use.

I am a Computer Science student and software developer living in Melbourne, Australia.

I currently have a special interest in functional programming.
